div.sent: The mixture of different ethnic and indigenous peoples has contributed to the variety in size, looks and appearances of the people of Bengal.
Similarly the varied mixture of linguistically different peoples has made their culture diversified and colourful.
However, in this rural and agriculture based country, the influence of rural culture is more prominent.
Besides, uncertain and whimsical behaviours of rivers and seasonal diversity of nature have enriched the Bangalee minds.
To understand Bangalee culture, we should keep in mind these diversities of Bengal.
No human being can ignore the impact of the nature, environment and climate of his or her birth or living place.
Bangalees also could not ignore the influence of nature in their culture.
The fertile land of this region has naturally inspired its people in agricultural work.
Their utensils were mostly made of clay.
Agriculture provided them cotton which inspired them to weave cloth.
Again, as this country possesses innumerable rivers, canals, and beels, fishing has become another profession of its people.
Agriculture, clay work, fishing and weaving - these four were the main occupations of the Bangalees from long time ago.
Gradually due to the necessities of society, professions like those of blacksmith, cobbler, wood workers, and goldsmith expanded.
The nature of Bengal is very mysterious.
Sometimes it is very kind and generous.
Again sometimes it is very whimsical and cruel.
Such cruelty is proved clearly in river erosions, droughts, floods and thunder strikes.
And that is why its people have always wanted to satisfy nature in various ways.
Many beliefs and customs with regard to man's encounter with nature exist among the rural people of Bengal.
Nature's whimsicality makes people suffer from an uncertainty about their future and fate.
This feeling of uncertainty has created a unique mystical sense in its people to come to an understanding with the Creator.
Such understanding has been expressed in the Baul, Bhatiali, Marfati and other folk songs of Bengal.
In spite of the diversity of the six seasons, hot weather prevails most of the time of the year except in winter.
So among the indigenous dresses of this region, sari, lungi, dhuti, wrapper, etc. were prevalent.
The people would wear these dresses so that air could pass easily through them and keep their bodies cool.
In rural areas, houses were made of bamboo, straw and clay.
Terracotta columns, folk stories written and pictures drawn on palm-tree leaves, wood artistry, shell work, clay pots and covers were all parts of our culture.
But Bangalees prefer to have vegetables, too.
Standing in the paddy fields, the farmers can feel the generosity of the sky and the earth.
While travelling by rivers, not only the fishermen and boatmen, but anyone becomes fascinated by the beauty and vast expanse of nature.
This nature is what has made the people here liberal and humanistic.
The main occupation of the people of Bengal is agriculture.
Agriculture depended solely on nature, especially on soil, cloud, rain, the sun, etc.
The Bangla calendar has been made mainly in accordance with the lifestyle of this agricultural society.
Many customs and festivals are prevalent centering agriculture.
Among these, Nabanna festival is observed in late autumn after harvesting new paddy.
In winter, there is a tradition of eating home- made pies made of new rice with much fun and festivity.
There are many songs paying homage to the soil in our folk and modern literature.
The first line of a patriotic song of Rabindranath Tagore is- Oh the soil of my country, I bow down my head to you.
Praise of soil has also been expressed in many of Kazi Nazrul Islam's songs.
From time immemorial, boatmen and fishermen remember Pir Badar while travelling by rivers and seas.
The people of the Sundarbans area remember Banbibi in many ways.
Various artisan classes of people including cobbler, blacksmith, potter, goldsmith etc have also expressed dedication and commitment to their professions through various rituals and festivals.
Artisans and businessmen open a Halkhata especially on the first day of every New Year.
Thus, different pictures of peoples life styles have been depicted in our folk culture.
Religion plays a great role in an individual's personal and social life.
Once upon a time in this country most of the people were worshippers of nature.
After Brahmana religion was preached, while some old gods-goddesses still remained, some new gods-goddesses were added.
Local devotional songs, mantras (spells), tantras, lyrics and folk stories in verse were prevalent.
Different Bedanta hymns and religious books written in Sanskrit by the Arjas were added to them.
As a practice of arts and crafts - making and decoration of idols, ornamentation, making pata paintings - were prevalent.
On the other hand, worship and prayer music, hymns, sacrificial rites were also prevalent.
The ritual of dances has been a part of Hindu religious ceremonies and festivals.
However, due to hard and fast caste rules of Hinduism, the lower class Hindus were attracted by the words of fraternity of Islam.
The Sufis mainly preached Islam in this country.
In the medieval period, Muslim societies were expanded by the people who came to this region from Iran, Turan and Afghan in quest of fortune.
Over the decades, a huge Muslim community has developed in this country.
However, following the tradition of the ancient agro-based rural society, the Hindus and the Muslims of this country have been living peacefully together.
The Buddha community in Bangladesh is very small.
The Buddhas arrange festivals on the occasion of Buddha Purnima to celebrate the birth of Gautam Buddha.
The Christian community is smaller than other communities in our country.
They also celebrate different types of religious festivals.
On Christmas Day, they arrange a large festival.
People of other communities are also invited.
Various ethnic groups and indigenous people celebrate various social and religious festivals throughout the year.
They arrange different types of joyful festivals in New Year, in spring, for weddings, etc.
This is the main teaching of all religions.
And the people of Bengal have followed this philosophy of life since time immemorial.
There is a proverb in Bengal A succession of festivities all the year round.
That is to say, here festivals are frequently.
Besides these, there are also religious festivals.
Apart from, these people also celebrate Nabanna and New Year.
Moreover, innumerable fairs are held on various occasions.
Most of these are village fair.
All the communities including Muslim, Hindu, Buddhist, Christian, and even minor ethnic groups arrange fair.
But there is no restriction for one community to visit the fair arranged by another community.
All go to each other's fair for purchase and sale.
Again some fairs are arranged by all together socially.
Again in many fairs, nagordola, magic, latikhela (play with sticks), kusti (wrestling), puppet show and bioscope etc are also arranged.
Bangla Academy arranges month- long book fair on the occasion of 21st February.
Generally adopting this fair, creative books are published.
So we cannot deny the contribution of 21st February to cultural life and literary practice of Bengali.
Nowadays book fair is also arranged along with celebrating 21st February in different districts of the country.
Another mentionable feature is the arrangement of fair in memory of the venerable sage.
Our land is very fertile and limitless is the generosity of its nature.
Our culture is enriched with diversity.
The people of Bengal are naturally very simple and easily satisfied.
Swami Vivekananda said He serves god, who loves living beings.
The Bengali poet Sheikh Fazlul Karim has said, Where is heaven, where is hell, who says those are far away?
Heaven and hell lie in the hearts of human beings, And so do evils and good.
